isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - CUMMINS CELECT 1992 - 1993 - ELECTRICAL OPERATION - ENGINE BRAKE SYSTEM

svcprocinfo.para: The ECM shares control of the Engine Brake System with the vehicle driver and the Antilock Brake System (ABS) if the vehicle is so equipped. The operator turns ON the engine brake ON/OFF switch and selects two-, four- or six-cylinder braking (the selection is different with the N14 than the L10) with the cylinder selector switch.

If the vehicle is equipped with ABS, the 12-volt power supply to the Engine Brake ON/OFF is through the ABS Engine Brake relay (286). This allows the ABS system to turn OFF the engine brake when wheel lockup is detected.
The ECM will not energize the engine brake enable relay if it senses any of the following conditions:

svcsubproc.title: Engine Brake On/Off Switch (246)
svcsubproc.para: The engine brake on/off switch is a 2-pole, single throw switch. One pole receives ignition power from 20A fuse F4, and with the switch in the ON position, sends 12V ignition power to the engine brake enable relay (248) common terminal, numbered 30 in the circuit diagram.

With ABS, the power passes through the Normally Closed contacts of the ABS Engine Brake Relay (286). The Normally Closed contacts open if the ABS system detects a wheel lockup is about to occur, turning the engine brake OFF.
The ABS system is discussed in GROUP 04 - BRAKES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

The other pole of the Engine Brake On/Off receives a 5V signal from ECM connector (252) terminal 10 on circuit 24R(5V). With the engine brake switch ON (switch closed), a 5V signal is sent on circuit 24AB through ECM connector (252) terminal 5 to the ECM.This signal tells the ECM that the engine brake switch is in the ON position.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Brake Enable Relay (248)
svcsubproc.para: When the engine brake On/Off switch is ON, 12V power is sent on circuit 24AA to terminal 30 of the engine brake relay. When the engine brake relay is energized, the power at terminal 30 goes from relay terminal 87 on circuit 24AD to the engine brake selector switch.

The engine brake enable relay is energized by 12 volts from the ECM 9-way connector (251) on circuit 24AA. The relay control coil is grounded by circuit 11-CB at J7 cab ground stud. The ECM enables the engine brake system by energizing the relay, if all previously discussed conditions are judged to be correct.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Brake Selector Switch (247)
svcsubproc.para: The engine brake selector switch receives power from the engine brake enable relay (248). The engine brake selector switch sends the 12-volt ignition power through the ECM 9-way connector (251) to selected engine brake solenoids. The power does not go through the ECM.

svcsubproc.title: Service Brake Switch (253)
svcsubproc.para: The service brake switch (closed with brake pedal released) serves both the cruise control and engine brake system. When the brakes are not applied, a 5V signal is applied to ECM connector (252) terminal 13. The service brake switch opens when the brakes are applied and the 5V is not applied to ECM connector (252) terminal 13.

svcsubproc.title: Clutch Switch (295)
svcsubproc.para: The clutch switch serves both the cruise and engine brake system. The switch is a normally open switch, adjusted to be closed when the clutch pedal is in the released position. With the clutch released, a 5V signal is applied through the clutch switch to ECM connector (252) terminal 4.
